newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Member states to attack beef reform proposals.
newsitem.headline: Member states to attack beef reform proposals.

text.p: Farm ministers are expected to attack on Monday beef reform proposals designed to cut output after demand plunged due to a public health scare over mad cow disease, EU officials said.
But they added that no decision could be taken next week because the European Parliament has not yet given an opinion.
"Discussions are likely to be heated and last late into the evening," said one official.
Germany and other major beef producers strongly oppose proposals made by the European Commission on July 30 (COM(96)422), saying they are unbalanced.
The proposals amend three regulations:
a) (REG(68)805) on the beef common market organisation.
b) (REG(92)1765) on the arable crops support system.
c) (REG(91)2328) on structural aids
The first proposal concerns:
- Abolishing the second aid payment for male cattle while increasing the first payment.
- Reducing the number of male cattle in each member state eligible for a special premium
- Slaughtering "meat" calves before 20 days or six weeks
- Accepting young cattle carcasses of between seven and nine months up to a weight of 300 kg.
- Increasing 1996 and 1997 intervention ceilings to 720,000 tonnes and 500,000 tonnes respectively, from 400,000 tonnes in 1996.
- Lowering stocking density to 1.2 animals per hectare, from 1.4 animals, for the special suckler cow premium.
- Ending certain special measures in the new east German states.
Commission officials warned that a 400,000 tonne beef intervention ceiling for 1996 was likely to be exceeded in early October and would have to be raised to stop a market collapse.
But it was uncertain if this could be done without ministerial approval.

The package, which would cost 1.3 billion Ecus ($1.7 billion) in 1997, would be financed by a reduction in compensation payments to cereals and oilseed farmers for income losses due to 1992 production-cutting reforms.
Only Britain, Sweden, Denmark and France support the plan.
Other countries said that strong cereals and oilseeds prices could swing the other way and were against a permanent cut in aid. Germany said the cost could be funded from savings in the farm budget.
